Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: The evolutionary consequences of subtle biases in the outcome of meiosis
Award.AbstractNarration:
The central assumption of Mendelian genetics is that an individual has as good a chance of passing on a gene that it received from its mother as one that it received from its father. In general, this assumption holds. Yet striking exceptions, in which either the maternal or paternal gene selfishly transmits itself to the next generation, are known from well-studied plants and animals. Are these cases rare exceptions, or are they the tip of a non-Mendelian iceberg? New genetic tools have now enabled researchers to find more subtle deviations from 50:50 ratios in wild plants and animals, suggesting that selfish genes may be more frequent and varied than previously appreciated. This is important because even a gene that causes a genetic abnormality can persist if it has a slightly better than 50:50 chance of making it to the next generation. This project will study the effects of non-50:50 transmission of genes on fitness in the moss model system Ceratodon purpureus. Combining new mathematical models and genetic data from this simple moss system will reveal insight into the genetics of infertility, the outcome of reproduction, and its influence on the structure of the genome.

This proposal presents a comprehensive plan to link genome-wide patterns of segregation distortion with fitness in the moss model system Ceratodon purpureus. The PIs central hypothesis is that segregation distortion is common across the genome and contributes to the maintenance of genetic variation for fitness, one of the central problems in evolutionary biology. The rationale for this proposal is to develop a new system to understand, at a mechanistic level, previously unexplored links between the outcome of meiosis and quantitative trait variation. To accomplish this goal, the PIs will combine genome-wide polymorphism data from natural populations of C. purpureus with new statistical models that treat segregation ratio as a quantitative trait whose architecture will be inferred. Because mosses have a haploid-dominant lifecycle, the PIs can efficiently survey the products of meiosis and generate simple yet powerful tests for specific associations between genes exhibiting biased transmission and fitness variation in natural populations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Infertility remains a major problem in human health as well as in breeding programs for domesticated plants and animals. Infertility may result from structural differences in one parent’s chromosomes, leading to karyotypic abnormalities in the offspring. However, infertility may arise, absent any structural variation, as a result of deleterious gene interactions among alleles at different loci. This kind of infertility is often observed when individuals of different species are crossed. However, such deleterious gene interactions also can contribute to infertility within species or interbreeding populations. The frequency of such deleterious interactions within species is unknown, in part because studying these interactions requires a pedigree with large sample sizes. This challenge can be overcome by studying gametes directly, but such an undertaking is technically difficult in most species. Here the PI and research team developed a system using a common moss, Ceratodon purpureus, that takes advantage of the fact that mosses have an extended part of the life cycle that is genetically equivalent to a gamete – that it, it has only one set of chromosomes.

 

To develop this research tool, the team worked with the DOE – Joint Genome Institute to sequence the genome of the moss Ceratodon purpureus. The genome sequence provides critical bioinformatic infrastructure for interpreting the results of the genetic analyses of infertility. Members of the team provided DNA and RNA to the sequencing facility for this effort, and conducted a variety of analyses on the sequence data that the facility provided. The research team also developed a protocol for genotyping moss individuals. This protocol was subsequently applied to moss populations as well as numerous other species of ecological, agricultural, or conservation interest. This work showed that although specific deleterious interactions are relatively rare, many such interactions may exist within an interbreeding population, with a major cumulative effect on infertility – in the moss, often more than half of the offspring were inviable. Collectively, the genome sequence and genotyping data generated here provide a roadmap for future investigations of specific genetic interactions contributing to infertility in this species.

 

A full time technician and three research undergraduates were directly supported by this project. More than twenty graduate students and visiting scientists were trained over this course of this project, and more than 25 undergraduates participated in this work. Work under this project contributed to 12 scientific publications and 25 research presentations.
